Welcome to Business Essentials

Please begin this module by reviewing the module handbook. You will find additional information such as the weekly schedule, learning methods, and essential resources. Students are responsible for reading the content of this document. For further information, contact your instructor

View module handbook

Module Outline

"Business Essentials" is a comprehensive course designed to equip you with a foundational understanding of contemporary business principles and the ability to analyse the external business environment. The module combines various teaching methodologies including lectures, group workshops, collaborative projects, and interactive assessments.

You'll be expected to actively engage in discussions, organize and review lecture notes, and undertake research on assigned topics. Course materials will be accessible via the Learning Management System, Canvas. This course aims to develop your critical thinking and analytical skills, preparing you for advanced study and a promising future in the business world.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

.

Apply knowledge on business and management principles suitable for further study.

.

Demonstrate understanding of key contemporary business concepts

.

Gain the ability to analyse the business external environment

Assessments

  • Weekly Quizzes: 5 weekly individual quizzes: 75%25 (15%25 per quiz)

  • Group Presentation: A final group presentation: 25%25

Assessment dates

Please note and manage your submission dates, they are important, and you must submit your assessments before the deadline. It is NOT possible to request an extension. The University will NOT send reminders if your submission is late or if you do not submit at all. If there are exceptional circumstances outside your control (for example, serious illness) affecting your ability to submit on time, you can download an Exceptional Circumstances (EC) formLinks to an external site..

Module Leader

.

Module Leader: Paul Varah

Paul Varah

Paul received a degree in HR Administration from University of Guelph before returning to his home city of Toronto, Canada to complete a post-diploma in HR Management at Seneca College. Paul then worked in several countries in Asia and the middle east before going to England for an M.Ed at the University of Nottingham. After short stints in northern Africa and the middle East, Paul returned to Vietnam where he worked for RMIT before joining BUV.

week1.body:
Welcome to week 1

This week we will take an in-depth look at what it means to be an entrepreneur and the risks and rewards they face in the current business environment. By the end of the week you will be able to generate a proposal for a new start-up business.

.

LESSON CONTENT

  1. Class 1: Lecture: An introduction to entrepreneurs, business and its environment

  2. Class 2: Workshop: You will create a proposal for a new business or start-up and make a business plan for this.

  3. Class 3: Practical: Finish your proposals, discuss as a class, and submit your work

  4. Class 4: Wrap and quiz

.

STUDY MATERIALS

  • Reading: Chapter one - Business and its Environment. Learn about growth, ownership, and business decisions

  • PPT: Review this week's lecture ppt.

  • PPT Lesson 2: Introduction to the activity

.

Ask questions, view comments, and get follow-up materials on the course noticeboard
